fields.label_text:
BALUSTRADE
Wrought and carved iron
Spain (Avila); c.1520-30

Made by Juan Frances. From a lateral chapel in the Cathedral of Avila. It is probably part of the same screen, or reja, as the crestings and ornaments on display further along the Gallery.

Museum No. 280:1-1879

SPANISH CHURCH SCREENS

The Church has always played an important role as patron of ironworkers, and no more so than in 16th century Spain. Huge rejas (screens) from this period still adorn many Spanish churches and cathedrals, serving to divide the liturgical spaces, most particularly the altar, choir and side chapels. Though often large in scale, some as much as 9 metres high, their makers used difficult and physically demanding techniques, often having to work the metal when cold. The common appearance of the maker's name included in the scheme suggests that these rejas were considered as masterpieces of the craft. They showed the latest ornamental vocabulary, and were topped with bold arabesque figures, scrolls and coats of arms, heightened with gilding and colour.

The portions of screen from Avila Cathedral displayed here and in Gallery 29A were made by Juan Frances, whose proud inscription adorns one of the crestings. Frances was working at Toledo Cathedral as early as 1482. He also made the screen for the choir at the Church of Alcala de Henares. The pulpit dated 1525 at Avila, of embossed and gilded iron, may also be his work.

4 COLUMNS
Wrought iron
Spain; 1520-30

Portion of a screen, or reja, made by Juan Frances. From a lateral chapel in the Cathedral of Avila. The embossed pattern is typical of the Spanish style known as 'plateresco'. Some of the original painting and gilding is still visible. The columns are probably part of the same screen as other crestings and ornaments on display in the Gallery.

Museum Nos 280:2-5-1879

SPANISH CHURCH SCREENS

The Church has always played an important role as patron of ironworkers, and no more so than in 16th century Spain. Huge rejas (screens) from this period still adorn many Spanish churches and cathedrals, serving to divide the liturgical spaces, most particularly the altar, choir and side chapels. STANDARD
Wrought iron
Spain; 1520-30

Portion of a screen, or reja, made by Juan Frances. From a lateral chapel in the Cathedral of Avila. The standard is probably part of the same screen as other crestings and ornaments on display in the Gallery.

Museum Nos 280:6-1879

TWO DOLPHINS
Wrought iron
Spain; c.1520-30

Ornaments from a screen, or reja, made by Juan Frances, from a lateral chapel in the Cathedral of Avila.

Museum Nos 280:7-8-1879

Wrought iron
Spain; c.1520-30

Museum Nos 280:9-11-1879

fields.descriptive_line: Screen, or reja from a lateral chapel in the Cathedral of Avila, probably made by the Workshop of Lorenzo of Avila with work by Juan Frances, wrought iron, Avila, ca. 1520-1530.
fields.physical_description:
Large ironwork screen.
[Ornament] Wrought iron dolphin ornament.
[Plinth] Wrought iron dolphin ornament.
[Ironwork] Wrought iron dolphin ornament.
[Ironwork [31 to 36]] Wrought iron dolphin ornament.
[Ironwork] Wrought iron cherub ornament.

fields.location: Medieval and Renaissance, room 50a, case EXP
fields.public_access_description: Screens were used to protect altars and private chapels. They were common in churches across Europe. This portion of the vast screen from Avila Cathedral consists of balusters, in a style favoured by the local ironwork specialist, Lorenzo de Avila, and his workshop. In earlier Spanish screens twisted bars were more common.
